body_html:
tf.image.decode_image is a wrapper of many other ops: decode_jpeg, decode_gif, decode_png, etc, so the output shape depends on the image type, and it cannot determine the shape of the output until actually seeing the content at execution time.

For now, you can simply replace the tf.image.decode_image with more specific ops, i.e., tf.image.decode_jpeg for jpeg, tf.image.decode_png for png, etc. (See https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/image for more details).
body_text:
tf.image.decode_image is a wrapper of many other ops: decode_jpeg, decode_gif, decode_png, etc, so the output shape depends on the image type, and it cannot determine the shape of the output until actually seeing the content at execution time.
For now, you can simply replace the tf.image.decode_image with more specific ops, i.e.,  tf.image.decode_jpeg for jpeg, tf.image.decode_png for png, etc.  (See https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/image for more details).
body:
`tf.image.decode_image` is a wrapper of many other ops: `decode_jpeg`, `decode_gif`, `decode_png`, etc, so the output shape depends on the image type, and it cannot determine the shape of the output until actually seeing the content at execution time.

For now, you can simply replace the `tf.image.decode_image` with more specific ops, i.e.,  `tf.image.decode_jpeg` for jpeg, `tf.image.decode_png` for png, etc.  (See https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/image for more details).
